Everlyne, 43, has been farming for the past 10 years. Through these years, she has gathered much experience and is considered among the best farmers in her village. She has been practicing mixed farming. Her primary sources of income have been milk, eggs, tea, crops and some small business ventures that help her make ends meet. Everlyne is very passionate about farming and loves cultivating her farm. That is why, every day, she wakes up very early to go to her farm to plow. 

Although she makes profits from farming, she is not comfortable and has always wanted to increase her income by selling cereals. That is why she is seeking this loan to buy cereals. Kenya's Nandihills area, one of the county's populated regions, has a high demand for cereals. This means that Everlyne could increase her profits and satisfy the demand that is there. Accessing funds has been a challenge for Everlyne, but she now feels relieved because Juhudi Kilimo is partnering with Kiva lenders to help aspiring women farmers like her turn their farming dreams into reality through training and loan financing. 

Everlyne believes that this loan will be of much help, and that she will be able to satisfy the demand for cereals. She also believes that the extra income she earns will enable a permanent change in her life and increase her business. Increased profits will allow Everlyne to repay this loan and secure the future of her school-going children.

loans.use: to buy cereals to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Meet Elizabeth. She is a 52-year-old woman who has been a farmer for 22 years. She is based in Taoto village, where she has a two-acre farm and a small house made out of earth, with two habitable rooms. On the farm, she grows vegetables that she uses for both consumption and sale. This business has enabled her to raise four children. Elizabeth's own upbringing was so difficult that she never had the privilege of attending school. Elizabeth is seeking a loan to venture into commercial poultry farming. With the loan, she will acquire a brood of hens that will lay eggs for food, sale and hatching. This business is projected to significantly increase her income. The birds will also bring life into her home, as they will be free-range and scratch the earth for bugs. The money from the investment will enable Elizabeth to afford basic needs and save up for the future. This loan will go a long way in empowering her to become a better entrepreneur and improve her family's living standards.

loans.use: To buy poultry

loans.name: Maria Angelica

texts.es:
María Angélica es una señora que ha aprendido sobre su carrera no solo en la universidad, sino también en forma empírica, de su día a día, de la vida. Esta mujer a seguir, tiene 39 años de edad y a pesar de las barreras económicas que ha tenido en ocasiones de su vida, ahora está en tercer año de la carrera de derecho con mención en gerencia empresarial. Ella es madre de dos niños de 7 y 20 años de edad, que no son más que su motivación para salir adelante.
Afortunadamente, además de contar con el apoyo de su familia, María Angélica es secretaria en una empresa privada. Ahora que está a punto de culminar sus estudios, solicita un préstamo para comprar una computadora, la cual servirá para poder actualizarse con las clases y trabajos de la universidad. Ella se siente apasionada con su carrera, pues considera que es una manera de ayudar a las personas a cumplir con sus derechos, por lo que sueña con ser asesora legal en un hospital, pues sabe que allí podrá cumplir con sus metas y propósitos.
texts.en:
Maria Angelica is a woman who has learned about her course of study not only in the university but also in an empirical from, from her daily life and from life. This woman, to continue, is 39 years old, and in spite of the economic barriers that she has had on occasions in her life, she is now in her third year of the program in law, with reference to business management. She is the mother of two children, ages 7 and 20, who are her motivation to get ahead.

Fortunately, in addition to having the support of her family, Maria Angelica is a secretary in a private business. Now that she is at the point of completing her studies, she is requesting a loan to purchase a computer, which will serve to bring her up to date with the classes and work at the university. She feels passionate about her career, since she feels that it is a way to help people to fulfill their rights. For this reason, she dreams of being a legal consultant in a hospital, since she knows that there she will be able to fulfill her goals and resolutions.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Commerçant de pièces détachées tricycle depuis 1992, Kodjo est un homme âgée de 42ans en situation d’handicape moteur. Marié, père de quatre enfants, il vit à Bé Apéyémé, une localité de Lomé capital du Togo. Il s’approvisionne une fois par mois dans le marché Méron au Nigéria. 
Kodjo sollicite un crédit pour augmenter son stock afin d’augmenter sa quantité d’achat et maximiser son bénéfice.
texts.en:
A bicycle spare-part salesman since 1992, Kodjo is a 42-year-old man with a motor disability. Married and a father of four, he lives in Be Apeyeme, a suburb of Lome, Togo’s capital. He gets his supplies once monthly at the Meron market, in Nigeria.

Kodjo is requesting a loan to increase his stock, his sales, and maximize his profits.

loans.use: to buy 18 tires, 35 inner tubes, 30 chain bearing units, and 33 hub bearings.

loans.name: Buguma Riz Group

texts.fr: Président du groupe BUGUMA RIZ, Wakalimbi s'est lancé dans l'activité agricole en 1988 après avoir quitté l'école et sous le contrôle de ses parents. Actuellement il exerce l'agriculture avec son épouse et cela lui permet de supporter ses besoins familiaux. Toutefois, il souhaiterai que la pratique agricole s'améliore avec l'usage des outils modernes pour que la production soit favorable et lui permette de remplir de mieux en mieux ses devoirs. Sur photo, Wakalimbi est en deuxième position portant une chemise bleue et ayant un carnet rose dans ses mains.
texts.en:
Wakalimbi is the president of group Buguma Riz. In 1988, after leaving school, he started in agriculture under his parents’ supervision. He now farms with his wife, allowing him to provide for his family’s needs. However, he would like to improve his agricultural practice with modern tools, to get a favorable yield and be able to fulfill his obligations better and better.

In the picture, Wakalimbi is in second position, wearing a blue shirt and with a pink notebook in his hands.

loans.use: to pay for plowing and weeding.

loans.name: Wedian

texts.en:
Wedian is a 32-year-old married mother of one child who has worked as a hairdresser from her house for seven years to help her husband in covering the needs and expenses of their family.

She is an ambitious and hard worker who is trying her best to develop her business. Thus today she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to buy necessary hair tools which will facilitate her work and satisfy her customers. 

Wedian hopes to expand her business more in the future to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy necessary hair tools

loans.name: Ismael

texts.en:
Ismael is thankful that he was granted a 15,000 PHP loan which he used to buy spare parts and for the maintenance of his tricycle. He also has a videoke business where he rents out video/karaoke machines to people who just want to unwind and relax. Through his earnings he is able to send his children to school and meet their daily living expense.

He would now like to apply for a 17,000 PHP loan which he will use to pay for the maintenance of his tricycle and videoke machine. It is important that his tricycle is always in a good running condition. And this coming Christmas Filipinos love to celebrate singing with friends and family. He is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given him for it will surely help cover their everyday needs and for the schooling of his children. He wishes everyone a Blessed Christmas!

Ismael aims to buy another tricycle and videoke unit to grow his business. He wants to give his children the best education until College. He only dreams of a comfortable life for his family. Every week he meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which he studies.

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and maintenance for his tricycle and his videoke unit as well.

loans.name: Augustin

texts.en:
Augustin is 37 years old. He is married with six children aged between 2 months and 14 years. Four of them go to school.  

He has a studio and has been in a business for 12 years. With the loan, he would like to buy more equipment such as cameras and film for sale. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest and pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: To buy more equipment such as camera and films for sale.

loans.name: Jose Domingo

texts.es:
José, de 44 años de edad, reside en un cantón, está acompañado y tiene tres hijos.- José solamente estudio sexto grado, por motivos económicos no siguió estudiando, su compañera de vida solo se dedica a los oficios domésticos de su hogar.

José, es agricultor, su padre le enseño este oficio desde que tenía 7 años edad, todos los años José siembra 7,000 metros cuadrados de maíz.-

El necesita el dinero para pagar ayudantes para cortar el maíz, pagar el alquiler de la maquina desgranadora de maíz y para pagar un vehículo que lleve los sacos de maíz hasta su casa y poder venderlos.

José, el próximo año desea sembrar el doble de lo que siempre hace, y recibir mayores ingresos para aportar más para las necesidades de su hogar.
texts.en:
José is 44 years old. He lives in a canton with his wife and three children. José himself only studied through the sixth grade, and then for financial reasons he did not continue his studies. His life partner is a homemaker.

José is a farmer, his own father began teaching him this trade when he was 7 years old. Every year, he plants 7,000 square meters of corn. He needs money to pay farm helpers to cut the corn, and to pay to rent the machine to de-stem the corn and to pay for a vehicle to carry the sacks of corn to his home so he will be able to sell them.

Next year José hopes to be able to sow double what he usually does and to obtain greater earnings to better support the needs of his household.

loans.use: to pay workers to cut his corn and to pay for a vehicle to haul the sacks of corn.

loans.name: Kristine

texts.en:
Kristine is 32 years old and she lives in Vanadzor city of the Lori region. Now Kristine lives with her mother since her husband is in the Federation to work abroad. Kristine has two sons. She has a medical education and now she works at the hospital as a nurse. 

Kristine is very worried and she needs this help greatly. Her smallest son has a disease and Kristine hopes that her baby is strong enough to overcome w it. She says that she feels that her son will recover, but for that she must bring her child to Yerevan city. She hopes that the doctors in the city will manage to help her son. 

She asks this loan of 200.000 AMD  in order to solve the greatest and the most important problem of her family; she will pay for her son’s treatment.

loans.use: pay for her son’s medical treatment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to get some construction done for his house.

loans.name: Junalyn

texts.en:
Her name is Junalyn. She is 31, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines, and  married to Francis, a tricycle driver. She has three children of whom one is in high school and the other two are still at the elementary level. She and her husband work hard to meet their everyday needs and to support their children's  schooling. 

Junalyn operates a tricycle and is also a dealer of personal products.  Her husband drives the tricycle that carries up to four passengers. In the Philippines especially in the provinces like Silang, a tricycle is a common means of transportation. Jeepneys and buses are limited. Very few people own a vehicle. The town people usually ride a tricycle from their homes to market, to church, to their friends' homes, and to other destinations within their community. They even transport from one town to the other. She earns a minimum of PHP 700 a day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting an PHP 11,000 loan which she will use for maintenance of her tricycle. She is positive that this will boost her income as tricycle transportation is really a need in their place.

Junalyn hopes to continue her business and buy another tricycle in the near future. She aims to send her children to the best schools in order for them to have a better future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and were she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for the maintenance of her tricycle unit.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Her name is Rosita, 53, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines, and married to Domingo, a tricycle driver. She has six children. She manages her household while operating the business. She works hard to augment their income to support and meet their daily personal and household needs and to send her four children to school. 

Rosita  operates a general store. In the Philippines. A general store is basically a small convenience store which sells fresh, dry, and packaged commodities directly to consumers. Almost all products are essential household items and food. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this, she also has a tricycle unit for transport service which her husband drives as added income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum net income of PHP 1000 a day. 

To help her continue operations of her general store business, she is requesting a PHP 14,000 loan which she will use to buy grocery items such as pasta, sacks of rice, charcoal, beverages, and other grocery stuff. She has to meet the increased demand of groceries this Christmas season. Part of the loan she will also use for the maintenance of her tricycle. Her store earnings are their resource to meet their daily expenses and to send her children to school. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her.

Rosita hopes to maintain and grow her business to uplift their lives. She strives to hard to give her children the best education and prays for a quiet and happy life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, beverages, and toiletries to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Celita

texts.en:
Ma. Celita is grateful that she was granted a 30,000 PHP loan which she used to buy fresh meat needed in her food stall business. Aside from her food stall, she also has a mini-lumber business from which she also has derived income for ten years already. Her earnings enables her to support her family and meet their daily basic needs. 

She would now like to apply for another 30,000 loan. This time she will use the loan to pay for raw wood and equipment for cutting wood to sell as lumber. People in the province still prefer wood in building their houses and rest houses for people from the city as it provides more comfort and warmth, the Philippines being a tropical country. Her income is a big help in their everyday expenses. She is thanking God and you in advance for a good return on her investment and  the financial assistance that will be given to her. She wishes everyone a Blessed Christmas!

Ma.Celita dreams to grow and be more successful in both her lumber and canteen business. She aims to improve their quality of life and prays for healthy living. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw wood and equipment to cut wood to sell as lumber.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Ldyia lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with one child. She takes care of additional family members. 

She operates a kiosk at the market selling soft drinks. She sells to all kinds of people on a retail basis. She has been in this business for the last three years. She works seven days a week. She has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX to buy crates of soda, passion fruits, oranges, watermelons and pineapples for making juice.

Her major challenges include high transportation costs and electricity, which increase her operational costs. Her goal is to open up another stall in the market. She lives in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and utility bills.

loans.use: To buy crates of tomatoes, onions, mangoes, oranges, and watermelons

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 41 years old and married, and, together with her spouse, blessed with one child.  She has a tailoring shop and has been running the business for 20 years. Right now she makes a monthly income of KES 10,000. 

She will use this loan to buy textile materials for making more dresses, blouses, shirts, and trousers. She will use the anticipated profits from her business to expand her business as well as repay the loan. 

This is her first loan term from VisionFund Kenya. In the future she hopes to expand her business and open another business.

loans.use: To buy textile materials for making clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy eggs wholesale and retail them.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is a 39-year-old married woman residing in Ormoc, Leyte. She is a mother of five children. Her oldest child is 16 and the youngest is 2. Cristina earns a living by raising and selling hogs. She has been in this kind of business for two years now. To augment income, she also farms, growing and selling vegetables.

Cristina is asking for a loan of 17,000 PHP to buy additional piglets, pig feed and vegetable seeds. These things are very essential in bringing her life back to normal. This loan could improve her way of living by creating higher yield, and hopefully she could support the needs of her growing children, especially by sending all her children to school for a brighter future.

Cristina hopes that she can handle both sources of her income successfully for a sustainable livelihood.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets, pig feed and vegetable seeds.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is grateful that she was granted a 40,000 PHP loan which she used to purchase various grocery items and products needed in her General Store. Through her earnings she is able to send her children to school and meet their daily living expense. By God's grace and hard work she was able to put up a small canteen to cater to her neighbors and their surrounding are.

She would now like to apply for a 50,000 PHP loan which she will use to pay for large quantities of groceries such as rice, pasta, can goods, coffee, soda, rice noodles, beverages and other grocery items.  She expects an increased demand of grocery items in preparation for Christmas Holiday. Her store earnings helps cover their everyday household needs and schooling of her children. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given her. She wishes everyone a Blessed Christmas!

Virginia dreams of having a bigger General Store and have her own place for her canteen. She aims to raise their standard of living and have a happy and peaceful life. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies .

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her general store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Dilver Antonio

texts.es:
Dilver, de 35 años de edad, está acompañado, estudió hasta séptimo grado de educación básica, su pareja trabaja como comerciante, tiene dos hijas que están pequeñas y aun no asisten a la escuela, en su casa vive su mamá. 

Dilver, trabaja con un camión halando arena, piedra, ladrillo, todo lo relacionado a la construcción, dicha labor la ha realizado por más de 10 años y lo aprendió por iniciativa propia.- En los ratos libres vende zapatos y radios portátiles.-

El préstamo lo utilizará para comprar repuestos para su camión, porque está en malas condiciones y por su seguridad necesita repararlo para seguir trabajando.

El sueño de Dilver es, seguir trabajando de esta manera para que sus hijas sean profesionales y tengan un mejor futuro.
texts.en:
Dilver, who is 35 years old, is married. He went to school through the seventh grade of basic education. His wife works in commerce. He has two daughters who are small and still don't go to school. His mother lives in his house.

Dilver works with his truck, hauling sand, rocks, bricks, and everything related to construction. He has done this work for more than 10 years, and he learned it on his own initiative. In his free time he sells shoes and portable radios.

He will use the loan to buy spare parts for his truck, because it is in bad condition, and for his safety he needs to repair it to continue working.

Dilver's dream is to continue working in this way so that his daughters can have careers and have a better future.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for his truck, because it is in bad condition, and for his safety he needs to repair it to continue working.

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Zainabu is in her mid-40s and is single with two kids, one of whom is still at school and the other is a grownup. Zainabu has been selling cold bites tambi to a certain school for six years now. She works from 6 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Zainabu's 6th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase her stock of tambi, which she distributed to many schools and was able to pay back all her loans successfully. She is happy with the loan, and appreciates Kiva for its support. She used profits to pay school fees and cover household expenses. She will use this loan to buy cooking oil, flour, sugar, salt and charcoal for cooking cold bites tambi. She dreams of building her own house.

Zainabu will make sure she pays her loan according to the loan schedule.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil, flour, sugar, salt and charcoal for cooking cold bites tambi.

loans.name: Tirso

texts.en:
Tirso is is thankful that he was granted a 19,000 PHP loan which he used to purchase various grocery items and products needed in his general store. With his earnings, he is able to send his children to school and meet their daily living expenses.

Tirso would now like to apply for a 25,000 PHP loan to buy large quantities of grocery items such as rice, coffee, pasta, soda, rice noodles,and canned goods, which he sells at retail price. He expects an increased demand of groceries now that Christmas is fast approaching. He is happy and is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to him, and for a good return on his investment. It will surely help him provide for his family's household needs and the school needs of his children.

Tirso dreams of having a bigger general store. He wants his children to finish their studies through college, to have a happy and abundant life and to have a better future. Every week, he meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which he studies .

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed for his business.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is grateful that she was granted a 35,000 PHP loan which she used to purchase various grocery items and products to sell in her general store. With her earnings, she is able to send her children to school and meet their daily living expenses. 

Rose would now like to apply for a 60,000 PHP loan which she will use to pay for large quantities of groceries such as pasta, noodles, rice, coffee, beverages and other grocery items. She expects an increased demand of grocery items this Christmas season. She is happy that it will surely improve her earnings which is a big help to cover her family's daily needs, her children's school needs, and to prepare for Christmas festivities. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to her. She wishes everyone a blessed Christmas!

Rose dreams of having a bigger general store to uplift their lives. She prays for a peaceful and happy family. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies .

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Ricarda

texts.es: La señora Ricarda, vive y trabaja en Cochabamba, económicamente es independiente, trabajadora y responsable; se dedica a la agricultura hace 36 años, siembra papa, locoto y zapallo como sus principales productos agrícolas en parte de su terreno propio ubicado en el mismo lugar. Produce con rotación de cultivos como vaina, repollo, achojcha y otros, cuenta con cabezas de ganado vacuno(2 lecheras, 6 vacas-yuntas y 3 terneros). La señora requiere un crédito para la compra de agroquímicos, abono para el cultivo de locoto y para pagar la mano de obra del fumigado de los cultivos  asi podrá mejorar su producción e ingresos para su familia.
texts.en: Ricarda lives and works in Cochabamba. She is financially independent, hardworking, and responsible. She has worked in agriculture for 36 years. She grows potatoes, peppers, and squash as her main agricultural products on part of her own land located in the same place. She produces with rotation crops such as legumes, cabbage, stuffing cucumbers, and others. She has cattle (2 dairy cows, 6 cart-pulling cows, and 3 calves). Ricarda needs a loan to buy agrochemicals and fertilizer to grow peppers and to pay labor costs to fumigate the crops. In this way she will be able to improve her production and family income.

loans.use: to buy agrochemicals and fertilizer to grow peppers and to pay labor costs to fumigate the crops. In this way she will be able to improve her production and family income.

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.en:
Bernardo is thankful that he was granted a 10,000 PHP loan which he used to buy spare parts and pay for the maintenance of his tricycle unit. He is glad he is able to provide for his family's daily needs. 

Bernardo would now like to apply for a 12,000 PHP loan to pay for the maintenance of his tricycle unit. It is important that his tricycle is always in good running condition to ensure efficient service. He is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to him. His earnings from his transportation business helps cover his family's basic needs and the schooling of his children.

Bernardo dreams of a more stable and prosperous life with his family. He hopes to buy another tricycle to grow his business. Every week, he meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which he studies.

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for the spare parts and maintenance of his tricycle unit.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is grateful that she was granted a 50,000 PHP loan, which she used to pay for fertilizer and farm inputs needed on her farm. With her earnings she is able to support her family and meet their basic daily needs.

Alma would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan, which she will use to buy more fertilizer and farm inputs for a more productive corn harvest. It will definitely help cover her family’s daily needs and her children’s education. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to her. She is wishing everyone a blessed Christmas! 

Alma dreams for her farm to grow and flourish and to have happy and prosperous life with her family. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizer and farm inputs for a more productive corn harvest.

loans.name: Nelson Balmore

texts.es:
Nelson, de 51 años de edad, esta acompañado, tiene una hija mayor de edad que ya no vive con el.- Nelson, no pudo estudiar y por esa razón decidió dedicarse a la agricultura, su compañera de vida se dedica a los oficios del hogar.
 
Nelson, aprendió el trabajo de la agricultura gracias a su padre, quien le enseño a muy temprana edad, para el ha sido el único trabajo que le a ayudado a generar ingresos para sustentar a su familia. 

El préstamo será para comprar una bolsa de semilla para sembrar maíz, cuatro sacos de abono, fertilizantes para la preparación de la tierra y también pagará la mano de obra que le ayudará a sembrar.

El sueño de Nelson es, vender su cosecha  a buen precio y de esa manera generar buenas ganancias para comprar insumos para volver a sembrar nuevamente y poder incrementar su producción y mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Nelson is 51 years old and lives with his partner. He has one grown-up daughter who no longer lives at home. Nelson was not able to study when he was young, so he decided to work as a farmer. His partner looks after their home. 

Nelson learned the work of farming thanks to his father, who taught him from a very young age. It has been his only job, and his means to earn an income and support his family.

He will use the loan to buy a bag of maize seed to plant, four bags of manure and fertilisers to prepare the soil, and to pay for labour to help him with the planting.

Nelson's dream is to sell his harvest at a good price and make a good profit, and therefore be able to buy more supplies which he will use to plant again and so increase his production and improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy maize seed, manure and fertilisers to prepare the soil, and labour to help him with the planting.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for her teaching degree.

loans.name: Antonina

texts.en:
Antonina is grateful that she was granted a 50,000 PHP loan, which she used to pay for a variety of fruits and veggies to sell at her fruit stand. She is thankful her store earnings enabled her to provide for the daily needs of her family.

To help her continue with her business, she is requesting another 50,000 PHP loan to buy more fruits, vegetables, and condiments as well to meet the increased demand this coming Christmas Season. It will definitely help support her family's daily household needs and the education of her child. She is thanking God and you in advance for a good return on her investment and the financial help that will be given to her. She wishes everyone a Blessed Christmas!

Antonina dreams of growing her fruit and vegetable stand and aims to give her family a better life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional fruit and vegetables to sell at her fruit stand.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to invest in her business, and to buy real and artificial flowers to sell.

loans.name: Twimukye Nabiteete Group

texts.en:
Leodina is the lady standing last on the right-hand side of the photo. She is a resident of Nyabiteete, Bugangari and a member of the Twimukye Nyabiteete group, which is made up eight members. Leodina is a 29-year-old lady married with five children; three of them attend school. She carries out agriculture as her major source of income. She deals most in coffee growing. Alongside agriculture, Leodina operates a small food stall that sells vegetables and fruits to supplement her income in the trading center; however, she is affected by limited capital to expand her stall. She applied for a loan of UGX 1,000,000 in order to boost her business by buying more stock of the same products so she can serve more customers and earn more income.
Leodina hopes that with the financial assistance from Ugafode, she will be able to meet her financial needs and improve her family's standard of living. She and other group members are thankful for the financial support, despite their status.

loans.use: To buy stock of tomatoes, vegetables and fruits for her food stall business.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with one child. She is not looking after any other family member. She has operated a beauty salon in the market for the last five years; she works seven days-a-week. She does not have any other source of income. She has requested a loan of Ugandan Shillings 300,000 from MCDT- SACCO to buy weaves, braids, rollers, treatments, and oils. Her challenges include seasonality, thieves, and debtors. Her dream is to buy a better hair dryer and good salon seats to attract more customers. She joined MCDT because of the relatively low interest charged on loans. She rents a house with access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include utilities and rent.

loans.use: To buy weaves, braids, hair relaxers, rollers, treatments, and oils for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Patricie

texts.en: Patricie is 50 years old. She is married with two children aged between 22 and 30 years, both of them are married. She sells food stuffs and has been in  business for 20 years. With the loan, she would like to buy more sorghum, ground nuts and beans to resell. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest and improve her standards of living.

loans.use: To buy more sorghum, ground nuts and beans to resell.

loans.name: Jhon Ronat

texts.es:
Al noroccidente de la provincia de pichincha en el Cantón pedro Vicente Maldonado tenemos el Recinto Pachijal un lugar tranquilo de clima cálido húmedo rodeado de gente amable y trabajadora, es un lugar turístico con muy buena acogida ya que se puede disfrutar de del maravilloso río Pachijal y su diversidad de flora y fauna silvestre. 
En este Recinto vive y tiene el negocio el señor Jhon un hombre luchador de 37 años es padre soltero tienen 2 hijos el mayor de 16 años y el ultimo de 1 año ellos no viven con el pero aprovecha todos los días para compartir momentos con sus hijos, el señor Jhon se dedica a la producción de cerdos aprendió de esta actividad en su niñez junto con sus padres, al mismo le dedica un promedio de 8 hora diarias, el viene de familia de bajos recursos económicos y no pudieron apoyarlo en su preparación solo tiene primaria, en la actualidad el se esfuerza cada dia para superarse y poder ayudar a que sus hijos se preparen y tengan mejores oportunidades que él. 
Este crédito lo invertirá para diversificar su negocio construirá unos galpones de pollos  para incrementar su producción, con esta nueva inversión mejoraran sus ingresos económicos, el señor Jhon agradece a Fundación Alternativa y a Kiva por el apoyo y la oportunidad brindada.
texts.en:
In the northwestern part of the Pichincha province, in the canton called Pedro Vicente Maldonado, the Pachijal precinct is found. It is a tranquil place with a warm, rainy climate and is surrounded by friendly and hardworking people. Is it is touristic location that is well received, since one can enjoy the marvelous Pachijal River and its diversity of wild flora and fauna.

In this precinct, Jhon lives and has his business. He is a determined, 37-year-old man. He is a single father with 2 children. His oldest child is 16 years old and the youngest is 1 year old. They do not live with him, but he takes advantage of every day to share moments with his children. Jhon makes a living in pig breeding. He learned this occupation as a child with his parents. He spends about 8 hours daily in this occupation. He comes from a family with few economic resources, and they could not support him in his education. He only went to elementary school. Currently, he works every day to better himself and to be able to help his children study so that they can have better opportunities than he did.

He will invest the loan to diversify his business. He will build some chicken coops to increase his production. With this new investment, his economic income will improve. Jhon is thankful to Fundación Alternative and to Kiva for the support and the opportunity he has been given.

loans.use: to build new chicken coops where he will diversify and breed chickens, so that he can help his children get ahead.

loans.name: Titus

texts.en:
Titus has a motorcycle transport business and a grocery business in Tala town. He has been running these businesses for ten years. He is 57 years old and married. He and his spouse have been blessed with three children.

He will use this loan to buy more stock of pawpaws and avocados to sell. He will use the anticipated profits to for pay school fees for his children. This is his fourth loan term from VisionFund Kenya, as he successfully repaid his previous loan. In the future, he hopes to have a prosperous business and to own a house for his family.

loans.use: to buy pawpaws and avocados to sell.

loans.name: Chantal

texts.en: Chantal is 27 years old. She is married with two children aged eight and 10 years; both of them go to school. She has a shop and has been in business for three years. With the loan, she would like to buy more brooms and stoves to resell. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy more brooms and stoves to resell.

loans.name: Rabqa

texts.en: Rabqa is a 56-year-old, married woman. She has been successfully running a small general store with her husband (also shown in the photo) at the corner of her house. Her husband also assists her by purchasing stocks of goods from the market and dealing with customers by sitting at the shop. Over time, they have become popular in their community for providing good quality products and make enough to meet the expenses of their two children. Currently, Rabqa requested a loan of 55,000 PKR to purchase more grocery items including grains, peas, flour, sugar, and tea to cater maximum customers for generating a healthier source of income. She is positive about her future earnings and will spend part of her income on buying more items for her store.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items including grains, peas, flour, sugar, and tea to cater maximum customers for generating a healthier source of income.

loans.name: Sa'ade

texts.en: Sa'ade is a maize farmer from Bature village in Kaduna state. Before she became a Babban Gona member, Sa'ade would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Sa'ade can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Sa'ade, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand her farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in her community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing.

loans.name: Ldyia

texts.en: Ldyia lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with two children, both are attending school. She is not looking after any other family member. She has operated a beauty salon in the market for the last three years; she works seven days-a-week. She does not have any other source of income. She has requested for a loan of Ugandan Shillings 300,000 from MCDT- SACCO to enable her to buy a stock of shampoo, braids, weaves, and portable hand dryer. Her challenges include seasonality, power shortages and debtors. Her dream is to expand her salon into a bridal shop. She joined MCDT because of the relatively low interest charged on loans. She lives in her own house with access to electricity and no piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy shampoo, oils, braids, weaves, and portable hand dryer for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Nada

texts.en: Nada is a 49-year-old married mother of three children, who has worked for 20 years as a hairdresser. She works from her house to help her husband to  cover the increasing needs and expenses of their family. Nada is a hard worker and a mother that is making many sacrifices to satisfy her children and develop her business; thus, today she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to pay her son's school tuition fees.  She also wants to buy tints of different colors to satisfy her customers. Nada hopes to open her own beauty salon in the future to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to pay her son's school tuition fees and buy tints for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Ruqiya

texts.en: Ruqiya is a 49-year-old married lady and has been running a small general store in her community for many years. She offers a variety of grocery items at a reasonable price and has retained many customers who regularly shop at her store. Ruqiya makes enough to provide for her family. To make her store fully stocked, she requested for a loan of 40,000 PKR which she will use  to buy rice, sugar, grains, biscuits, oil, and flour from the market at lower rates to make stock available for her customers. In this way, she will be able to meet the increasing demand consistently. Ruqiya wishes to utilize part of her revenues on providing good quality life to her family members.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, grains, biscuits, oil, and flour from the market at lower rates to make stock available for her customers.

loans.name: Airas

texts.en:
Airas is 58 years old, and married.  She is a very talented lady and excels in her work of stitching, earning a lot of appreciation from her community. Some years ago she started her business of tailoring while running her household activities, working hard to continually provide income for the everyday expenses of her famiy.  

Airas has requested for a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase more spools of thread, ribbon, cloth, needles, and scissors for stitching up more dresses on time which will giver her a boost in her earnings and provide a quality life to her family members.

loans.use: to purchase more spools of thread, ribbon, cloth, needles, and scissors for stitching up more dresses.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is single with four children; two of whom are attending school. She is not looking after any other family member. She has been selling second hand clothes in the market for the last five years. She works six days-a-week. She also sells snacks pancakes, fried cassava and sweet potatoes and half cakes to supplement her income. She has requested for a loan of Ugandan Shillings 300,000 from MCDT- SACCO to enable her to buy more stocks of skirts, blouses, and jackets for sale. Her challenges include seasonality and changes in prices. Her dream is to build her own work premises. She resides in rented house with access to electricity and no access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees.

loans.use: To buy a bale of used clothes to sell.

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en: Haruna is a maize farmer. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Haruna would have to sell his maize for low prices, soon after harvest, to address his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Haruna can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Like other Babban Gona members, Haruna is looking to earn a better income to provide more food and clothing for his family.  He hopes to make more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing, thereby eliminating the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Fouzia

texts.en:
Fouzia is a 40-year-old married woman who has been running a school for 13 years. Fouzia was always interested in providing education to the children in her community, and was determined to be successful. Two years ago, she saved enough money to buy her own building for her school, but it still requires some work.

A loan of PKR 110,000 will allow her to buy furniture and a swing set for her students and to construct a gate for her school. Fouzia's mission is to continue running this school for the long run and to expand by enrolling more students.

loans.use: to buy furniture and a swing set for her students and to construct a gate for her school.

loans.name: Abdu

texts.en: Abdu is a maize farmer from Makera village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Abdu would have to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to address his immediate cash needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Abdu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. Abdu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland.  He hopes to ensure that other members of his community are lifted out of poverty.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing thereby eliminating the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Idris

texts.en:
Idris is a maize farmer from Hayin Malam Yako village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Idris would have to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to address his immediate cash needs. With this loan, and Babban Gona’s support, Idris can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest.

Idris, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland. He hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to buy food and clothing thereby eliminating the pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Wallen

texts.en:
Wallen is now 34 years old. She used her previous loan to buy building materials, such as cement, to renovate her rental houses. It was profitable and she was able to repay the loan.

She has requested her fourth loan from VisionFund Kenya. She will use this loan amount to buy additional building materials for renovation, including timber, wall paint, iron sheets, ceiling boards and water pipes. This will enable her to keep the rental houses in good condition and attract more tenants.

She will use the anticipated profits to build more rental houses. Wallen successfully repaid her previous loans and hopes to expand her business and be more successful.

loans.use: to buy building materials for renovating her rental houses.

loans.name: Xayyam

texts.en: Xayyam is a 26-year-old, single man. He is an IDP (internally displaced person) and lives with his family in Bilasuvar region. Xayyam never went to school because of his parents' financial situation and the war. He is a worker, but his salary is low. Because of that, he chooses gardening as additional   source of income. They have a big land, but he has doesn't have money to supply crops, trees, and garden tools. He hopes that only Kiva will be able to support him, he needs a loan 1200 AZN and this is going to be his first loan. Xayyam plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family and to get married.

loans.use: to supply crops, trees and garden tools for his farming business.

loans.name: David Joel

texts.es:
David, de 24 años de edad, es agricultor, estudió hasta noveno grado de educación básica, está acompañado  y tiene un hijo, su pareja se dedica a los oficios domésticos.

David, trabaja con ganado bovino, lo ha hecho por más de 3 años, oficio que aprendió de su padre, decidió dedicarse a tiempo completo a este trabajo para obtener un mejor ingreso económico para el sustento de su familia, la distancia que camina para ir hasta donde tiene el ganado es de 2 kilómetros, su padre también le ayuda.

El utilizará el préstamo para comprar ganado de repasto, ya que al tener más ganado mejorará su calidad de vida y podrá darle más ayuda a su hijo para que estudie y sea un profesional de éxito.
texts.en:
David is 24 years old and is a farmer. He went to school up to ninth grade. He has a partner and one child; his partner takes care of their home. 

David works with cattle, which he has done for more than three years, having learned the job from his father. He decided to work full time in this area in order to earn a better income to support his family. He walks a distance of two kilometres every day to reach the place where he keeps his cattle. His father also helps him in his work.

He will use the loan to buy cattle to fatten, as with more cattle his quality of life will improve and he will be able to give more support to his child to study and become a successful professional.

loans.use: to buy cattle to fatten.

loans.name: Shivshakti Shg Group

texts.en:
Jyoti is 39 years old, married, and has four children. Jyoti works in agriculture raising goats. Jyoti has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is lack of capital.

In early 2014, Jyoti joined People's Forum to get a loan to increase her business. This was her first loan. Jyoti is the group leader of the Shivshakti Shg group, which consists of 14 members. She, along with her group, is requesting this loan, and she will use her portion to purchase baby goats to raise and sell. In the future, Jyoti hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well, and to build a new house.

loans.use: to purchase baby goats to raise and sell.

loans.name: Kosar

texts.en:
Kosar is a married 53-year-old woman with two children. She is a vigorous lady who, for the past many years, has been running a cloth business. She buys material (various fabrics, colors and designs) from the market at wholesale rates and then sells them to the people of her community. She has a diverse customer base and is able to earn enough through her business.

She requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to buy a wide variety of cloth in different colors and designs to attract more customers and to expand her business. She hopes to have a good experience with this new loan. Kosar expects a boost in her earnings with the loan and plans to spend the part of her profits for the betterment of her family members.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of cloth in different colors and designs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase construction materials to add another room to her house.

loans.name: Naomi I.

texts.en: Naomi is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. She joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: James, Aminu and Yakubu.  Before she became a Babban Gona member, Naomi would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for her immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Naomi can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Naomi spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to make more money for herself and her family.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to raise the ceiling of his home, to improve its safety and comfort.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase goats to raise and sell.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with four children, three of whom attend school. She is also looking after her brothers' children.

Aida operates a restaurant at the market for the last eight years, working six days a week. She also earns income from poultry farming. She has requested a 200,000 UGX loan from MCDT-SACCO to buy cooking oil, beans, flour, and bunches of green bananas. Her challenges include transportation and seasonality. Her dream is to acquire more land for farming.

She stays in her house with access to both electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school dues.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil, beans, flour, and bunches of green bananas.

loans.name: Nav Durga Sss Group

texts.en:
These women belong to the self help group “Nav Durga Sss”. This group is located in the district of Chhindwara, part of the state of Madhya Pradesh, India. 

One member is Nirmala. She is a divorced woman, 42 years old, and has one daughter. Nirmala alternates her daily activities with the business of selling fresh fruits, such as apples, oranges, bananas, etc., among others. Nirmala has worked in this business for a while, and it is going very well thanks to her daily hard work. She wants to be able to continue working in her business in order to keep supporting her daughter's education. This member, along with her group, has requested a loan, and she will use her portion to buy fruits and vegetables in bulk to resell. The other members work selling milk, selling woven goods, etc. 

Nirmala is grateful to those who form part of this dream, and she promises to repay the loan on time and in the prescribed manner.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables in bulk to resell

loans.name: Yahaya

texts.en: Yahaya is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. Yahaya joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children, Yuwana, Linas and Salama.  Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yahaya would have to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest.  This was necessary to address his immediate cash needs, such as food and clothing. With this loan, and Babban Gona’s support, Yahaya can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Yahaya  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Abida

texts.en: Abida is a responsible mother in Lahore who has always been supportive of her three children. She is loving and caring. One of her children is a rickshaw driver by profession. He is hardworking and obedient. He provides transportation services in Lahore. His contribution is significant to the family as they are not financially stable. Due to constant driving, the rickshaw needs some repairs. Without the repair he has to bear substantial loss of income. Abida has, therefore, requested a loan to help her son with the repair. She is pleased and thankful to Brac Pakistan and Kiva.

loans.use: to cover the repair cost of her son's rickshaw.

loans.name: Racha

texts.en: Racha is a single 22-year-old Lebanese woman. She lives with her parents and two siblings. Her father is the main income source for the family, and he is a really hard worker expending great effort to support his family. Three years ago, in order to help her father with the household expenses, Racha started her own business, selling cosmetics and beauty products. Her work is based at her house, where she welcomes her customers to sell them her particular products. Today, she is asking to borrow a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to purchase cosmetics as she wishes to increase her business sales and thus her income. Racha states that she is very excited to receive the loan as she has no doubt that it will bring positive results.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics as she wishes to increase her business sales

loans.name: Bashiran

texts.en: Bashiran is a 45-year-old married woman with five children. She has been selling animals with her husband for many years. Bashiran fully supports and assists her husband with his work. Now, she has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR. She wants to use this loan amount to purchase more cattle to resell in the market. She desires to improving her standard of living thorough her efforts.

loans.use: to purchase more cattle to sell.

loans.name: Yusuf Nomau

texts.en: Yusuf Nomau is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. He joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Simon, Hosea and Afiniki. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Yusuf Nomau would have had to sell his maize at low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate cash needs, such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Yusuf Nomau can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. When asked, Yusuf Nomau  spoke of his  ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, hoping eventually to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for school fees and uniforms thereby eliminating pressure to sell corn for low prices at harvest.

loans.name: Kousar

texts.en: Kousar is a 35-year-old married woman with three children. She has had a business buying and selling animals with the help of her husband for many years. Her business has provided her family with a decent life and she is very motivated to provide them with a good education, food and clothing. Kousar has requested a loan of 40,000 Pakistani rupees (PKR). She intends to use this to buy more baby goats and calves to cater for more customers. She is hopeful that her business will generate greater revenue in the future.

loans.use: to buy more baby goats and calves to sell.

loans.name: Shazia

texts.en: Shazia  is a 32-year-old married woman. She runs a business of milk selling with her husband. She has buffaloes and cows for milk production. Her husband sells the milk in nearby areas. Shazia’s job is to look after the buffaloes and collect the milk from them. Together, both husband and wife are supporting their family. They also sell animals on a seasonal basis to generate extra income. However, they need to earn more for their everyday expenditures. Therefore, Shazia  has requested 55,000 PKR  to buy one more buffalo to cater to more customers and thus provide a better standard of living for her family members.

loans.use: to buy one more buffalo to cater to more customers and thus provide a better standard of living for her family members.

loans.name: Ado

texts.en: Ado is a maize farmer and a member of Babban Gona. He joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children: Abubakar, Yosiya and Rhut. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Ado would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest, to cater for his family's immediate  needs such as food and clothing. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, he can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% higher than the market price at harvest. When asked, Ado spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to pay for his children's school fees and uniforms

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes is thankful that she was granted a PHP 10,000 loan, which she used to buy raw ingredients needed in making native delicacies. Through her earnings she is able to support her family and meet their daily basic needs.

She would like now to apply for PHP 15,000, which she will use to buy flour, eggs, sugar and coconut to make native delicacies (rice cake, "puto") to meet the Christmas orders of her customers in preparation for the Christmas holiday. She looks forward for increased sales and income this coming holiday. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to her. She wishes everyone a Blessed Christmas!

She dreams of having a stall in a commercial area and buying a vehicle to easily transport rice cakes to her customers. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

 * All CCT community partner/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like sticky rice, flour, sugar and coconut milk to make native delicacies.

loans.name: Merlina

texts.en:
Merlina is thankful that she was granted a 12,000 PHP loan, which she used to buy school/office supplies to expand her product inventory. Through her earnings, she is able to send her children to school and meet their daily living expenses. 

She would now like to apply for another 12,000 PHP loan, which she will use to buy more school/office supplies to add to her store. She knows that more items in her store will yield more sales and thus increase her earnings. Her income from her store is a stable source to sustain her family's basic needs and for the education of her children. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to her. 

Merlina dreams of having a bigger store and aims to give her children the best education for a better future. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies .

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for school/office supplies to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Angelena

texts.en:
Her name is Angelena. She is 48 and a resident of Dasmarinas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to John Rey, a construction worker, and has two children who are still in the elementary Level in school. She manages her household while operating a business. She works hard to augment their income to support and meet their daily personal, household needs and to send her children to school. 

Angelena operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a general store is basically a small convenience store which sells fresh, dry, and packaged commodities directly to consumers. Almost all products are essential household items and food. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum net income of PHP 1,000 a day. 

To help her continue operations of her general store business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan, which she will use to buy grocery items such as sacks of rice, charcoal, noodles, soda and other grocery stuff. She is positive that it will boost her income as she expands her business. She is glad that her store earnings help provide for her family's daily household and personal needs. She is thanking God and you in advance for the financial help that will be given to her.  She wishes everyone a Blessed Christmas!

Angelena hopes to maintain and grow her business so she can have a better life. She strives hard to give her children the best education possible and prays for a quiet and happy life. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, beverages and toiletries to sell at her store.

loans.name: Philibus

texts.en:
Philibus is a maize farmer and a member of the Babban Gona Farmers Organization. He joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children Josape, Ana and Anoch. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Philibus would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate needs such as food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Philibus can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. When asked, he spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure they are educated enough to find professional jobs.

loans.use: to store the maize he grows so he can sell it for a higher price than immediately post-harvest.

loans.name: Mika

texts.en:
Mika is a maize farmer from Zaki village in Kaduna state. Before becoming a Babban Gona Farmers Organization member, Mika would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Mika can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. Mika, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to store his maize after harvest so that he can sell it later at a higher price.

loans.name: Nubar

texts.en:
Nubar is a 22-year-old married woman who has a one-year-old daughter. She never went to school because of her parents' financial situation and the war. She is an internally displaced person who lives with her family in the Bilasuvar region of Azerbaijan. They are living in hard conditions as a result, and Nubar works every day without rest.  

She grows fruits and vegetables, a trade she learned from her father. This has allowed her to move her family ahead. Nubar's day starts at 6 a.m. because she wakes up very early to milk a cow. She is requesting a loan from Aqroinvest Credit Union to buy seed, manure and pesticides. Her dream is to see her  child graduate with a college degree because she was not able to do it herself.

loans.use: to buy seeds, manure and pesticides

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 3 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members. Susan owns a pub. She has been in this business for over 12 years, and she works 6 days a week. Susan sells her products in her pub on a retail basis from home. 

She has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva Field Partner MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more jerrycans of local gin, crates of beer and soda. Her main business challenges are power shortages and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesaler and to buy a plot of land and build her own house. Susan lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, food and medication.

loans.use: to buy jerrycans of local brew, crates of beer and soda

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: Nasreen is a 45-year-old married woman and the mother of 6 children. In order to support her husband in taking care of the family, she began a business selling milk. She is known in her town for providing good quality milk. She owns buffaloes for milking and is happily supporting her family with the income this generates. She has requested a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase another buffalo to increase her sales and generate more income to cover her daily expenses.

loans.use: to purchase another buffalo to increase her milk sales

loans.name: Sani

texts.en:
Sani is a maize farmer and a member of the Babban Gona Farmers Organization. Sani joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for his children Comfort, Gift and Bege. Before becoming a Babban Gona member, Sani would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate needs like food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Sani can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. When asked, Sani spoke of his ambition to use the additional income to educate his children, eventually hoping to ensure they are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to store the maize he grows so that he can sell it later at a higher price

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to grow her husband's oil sale business

loans.name: Naom

texts.en:
Naom is a rural farmer in Nandihills, Kenya, an area known for producing the best bananas in the world. She is blessed with three children, and has been practicing mixed farming for the past ten years. On her farm, Naom grows maize, has a dairy cow, and keeps poultry. She sells milk, eggs, and maize, and when she is not farming, she engages in some personal business to help supplement the meager income she earns. However, despite the meager earnings, farming gives her a great sense of satisfaction. 

"I enjoy it most when I see customers come back for my products because it shows me that I am meeting their needs!" she says. Naom's biggest challenge is drought. The long dry season can lead to crop failures and poor yields. For a farmer, this means  business losses and lack of food for the family. Because of this challenge, Naom formed a group and joined Juhudi Kilimo, a microfinance organization that supports small rural farmers. 

With her previous loan, Naom purchased a dairy cow that she later named Mrembo (Swahili for beautiful). Mrembo produces milk daily, which Naom sells to a co-operative. "The money from milk comes regularly and is not very affected by sudden changes in weather if you have stored feed," says Naom. The money Naom earned from selling the milk was adequate to repay her loan. 

Today, she is seeking a new loan to buy another dairy cow and is planning to become a full-fledged dairy farmer. Her future plan is to construct a zero-grazing unit. That way, she can use the grazing field to plant fodder and prepare silage. With this loan, Naom is going to grow into a very successful dairy farmer. All she wants is for her family to enjoy the abundance of life, good health, and a good livelihood.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Marika

texts.en: Marika is 26 years old. She lives with her husband Giorgi in Zugdidi district. Giorgi works as a security guard and gets a monthly salary. Marika trades used clothes and generates income, but she needs to start an additional business and increase her income. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, is enabling her to get a loan of $2,100. With the credit, she will purchase a stock of walnuts and will resell it at a higher price. This will give her an additional source of income, and she will expand her trading business. Marika is very hardworking motivated woman and awaits your support.

loans.use: to start up an additional business in order to increase her family's income

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is a 33-year-old married man with a university education living with his family in Haja, Yemen. He is the sole breadwinner for the family. He needs to a new phone to connect with other people, but he doesn't have enough money. For this reason, he applied for a loan of 90,000 YER from AMB in order to purchase a Samsung Galaxy phone. Mohammed eventually hopes to provide his family with all the home appliances they need.

loans.use: to purchase a mobile phone

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a maize farmer from Mayau Rumi village in Kaduna state. Before he became a Babban Gona member, Joseph would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate needs. With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Joseph can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. Joseph, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to ensure his children are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to store his maize crop so that he can sell it later at a higher price

loans.name: Perafeen

texts.en: Perafeen is 56 years old and is a married woman. She deals in the business of selling animals. She buys animals (baby goats and calves) at low prices, brings them up and then sells them at the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute to her family's income. She also sells milk to generate an extra amount of income. She needs to improve her business to bear her household expenses. For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied a loan of 40,000 PKR to purchase more animals and grow her sales. She is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan, Perafeen will definitely expand her business and income.

loans.use: to purchase more animals to sell to grow her income.

loans.name: Eli

texts.en:
Eli is a maize farmer and a member of the Babban Gona Farmers Organization. She joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children Toni, Nasiru and Fati.  Before becoming a Babban Gona member, Eli would have had to sell her maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet her immediate needs like food and clothing. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Eli can now store her maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. When asked, Eli  spoke of her ambition to use the additional income to educate her children, eventually hoping to ensure they are educated and have professional jobs.

loans.use: to store her maize crop so she can sell it later for a higher price.

loans.name: Shafiu

texts.en:
Shafiu is a maize farmer from Mafera village in Kaduna state. Before becoming a Babban Gona member, Shafiu would have had to sell his maize for low prices soon after harvest to meet his immediate needs. 

With this loan and Babban Gona’s support, Shafiu can now store his maize at harvest time and sell it a few months later for up to 40% more than the market price at harvest. Shafiu, like other members of Babban Gona, intends to use the extra income to expand his farmland, and hopes to become the most profitable farmer in his community.

loans.use: to store his maize crop so he can sell it later at a higher price.

loans.name: Nurlan

texts.en:
Nurlan is a married man who is 23 years old and lives with his family of four. He is an internally displaced person and lives with his wife and parents in the Bilasuvar IDP Settlement. For the past two years, he has sold gardening equipment as a source of income. He does not have enough money to supply crops, trees and garden tools to all of his customers. 

He hopes that Kiva lenders will be able to support him. He needs a loan 500 AZN and this is going to be his second loan. Nurlan plans to use the additional revenue generated from his business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to supply crops, trees and garden tools

loans.name: Donathile

texts.en: Donathile is 31 years old. She is married with 3 children aged between 2 months and 8 years. All of them go to school. She sells food and has been running her business for 15 years. With this loan, she would like to buy more mats, brooms and cases for sale. The profits from the business will be used to reinvest in her business and pay school fees for her children.
